title: Working with Product models and Product instances
content:
Product models

Product models represent the products a company is selling. Product models can be a multi-level classification you can use to structure your products to help define how they are managed.

A product model can be of type

  • Category: A classification or grouping of similar products.

  • Product: An individual product.

  • Bundle: A collection of multiple products that are packaged together and offered as a single unit to the user.

Product models can have versions and modules.

  • Product versions define the available versions of a product, including the maintenance dates.

  • Product modules allow breaking down the product into components, which can be used in the request handling to classify and route the requests.

User options can be used to have one product model for several variants of the product. For example, if there is a product available in green, red or blue, you can add an user option color, which is then set when the product model is instantiated. There is no need to have a product model for each color.

Often, the first level of the product model is more of a category than a product which can be instantiated. For example: Software. At the next level down, the models might be Software 1, Software 2, and so on.

Product models of type Product can be related to Offerings and Articles. This ensures that only users with an entitlement to these products, can see the article and offering. In the case of a hierarchical product model, it is not supported to have a parent model related with an Offering and Article to restrict the access for child product models.

Product instance

Product instances represent the product models sold to a customer. Only product models of type Product or Bundle can become a product instance. The product instance inherits all user options configured at the product model to track the data required for the sold product. This allows you, for example, to benefit from the available standard multilevel classification and maximize consistent record-keeping.

When instantiating product models, the taxonomy information can be used to filter only relevant products and bundles for product instances. A product instance is owned by a customer and can have a related product version, environment and contract. In case a customer purchased a bundle, each item in the bundle will have a separate product instance created when the bundle is instantiated. Finally the customer can create tickets against the product instances they own.

Simple product model structure

In this example, a simple product model structure is illustrated. Each of the two categories contains three product models.

Product model
Model type: Category Model type: Product Parent Model
Software SW Product 1 Software
Software SW Product 2 Software
Software SW Product 3 Software
Hardware HW Product 1 Hardware
Hardware HW Product 2 Hardware
Hardware HW Product 3 Hardware
Every product model of the model type "Product" or "Bundle" can be:

  • Added to contracts to track which products are covered by a contract made with a customer.

  • Added to licenses to track which products are covered by a license sold to a customer.

  • Used to create product instances owned by a customer, to entitle the customer to create requests against the product instance. If a contract is added to the product instance, the product instance is shown in the contract as well.

Simple product model structure with bundle

In this example, a product model structure with a bundle is illustrated. This product model structure contains a category Software. The category includes two products and one bundle.

The bundle itself references the two product models SW Product 1 and SW Product 2.

All records from the product models of the model type "Product" or "Bundle" can be referenced in licenses and contracts.

If the bundle gets instantiated (purchased by the customer), each item in the bundle creates its own product instance. The product instance includes a reference to the following:

  • The bundle from the Product model entity

  • The product from the Product model entity

If a product model of the type "Product" is instantiated, the product instance is directly created.

Advanced product model structure

In this example, an advanced product model structure is illustrated. It consists of several hierarchical elements to structure the products as often required in large companies. Product models include a field called Taxonomy. The taxonomy field helps classify different categories and products even further. The list used for the taxonomy can be modified by customers as required.

In this example, the taxonomy (Level 1 to Level 6) can be used to have an additional classification criteria beyond the model type. The first four layers (Level 1 to 4) in the example below are product models of type "category", these layers create the required hierarchy and organize the products consumed by the customer. Level 5 in this example, is the product which the customer can consume, hence used in product instances, articles and offerings. In this example Level 5 represents the products as its known by the customer.

If required, you may want to track different SKUs related to a product in an even more granular way. You can add such items as child to the products at level 5. The product models at level 6 might be used to track in contracts and licenses which SKU the customer purchased.

All records from the product models of model type "Product" or "Bundle" can be referenced in licenses and contracts.

If the bundle gets instantiated (purchased by the customer), each item in the bundle creates its own product instance. The product instance includes a reference to the following:

  • The bundle from the Product model entity

  • The product from the Product model entity

If a product model of type "Product" gets instantiated the product instance it directly created. We recommend filtering the correct level as required when creating product instances. In the example above, the system should only accept products or bundles at level 5 of the hierachy to create product instances.

To adjust the filter according to your needs:

  1. Go to Studio > Product Instance > Processes and Rules > Rendering forms.
  2. Change the "Define suggested values for Product Models..." rule to add the filter for the Taxonomy - Level 5.
  3. Go to Studio > Offering / Article > Processes and Rules > Rendering forms.
  4. Add the Define suggested values for relationship types based on the filter rule.
